statement.text: NPV analysis must use incremental cash flows - the additional cash flows that occur only because of the investment decision. This requires identifying and including opportunity costs, externalities (synergies and cannibalization), and excluding sunk costs.

explanation.intuition: When evaluating a project, ask: 'What cash flows change if we do this project versus if we don't?' Only those changes matter for the decision. Money already spent (sunk costs) doesn't change, so it's irrelevant. Opportunity costs are real costs even if no check is written.
explanation.key_insight: The hardest part of capital budgeting isn't the math - it's correctly identifying which cash flows to include. The three key principles are: (1) Ignore sunk costs, (2) Include opportunity costs, (3) Include side effects (cannibalization, synergies).
explanation.technical_details: Incremental cash flow = CF(with project) - CF(without project). This 'with/without' principle applies to every line item. For example, if a new product reduces sales of an existing product (cannibalization), that lost revenue is an incremental cost of the new project.

sunk_costs.definition: Costs already incurred that cannot be recovered
sunk_costs.example: R&D already spent on product development, market research already paid for

opportunity_costs.definition: Value of the best alternative use of resources
opportunity_costs.example: Using a building you own means losing potential rental income

cannibalization.definition: New product sales that come at expense of existing products
cannibalization.example: New iPhone model reduces sales of older iPhone models

synergies.definition: Positive spillovers to other parts of the business
synergies.example: New product brings customers who also buy existing products

working_capital.definition: Investment in inventory, receivables, less payables
working_capital.example: Need to build inventory before product launch

definitions_glossary.incremental_cash_flow: The change in cash flow caused by a decision
definitions_glossary.with_without_principle: Compare scenarios with and without the project
definitions_glossary.allocated_overhead: Fixed costs allocated to projects - often NOT incremental

learning_objectives: Apply the with/without principle to identify incremental cash flows
Correctly treat sunk costs, opportunity costs, and externalities
Avoid common errors in project cash flow analysis
common_errors: Ignoring opportunity costs (free use of company resources)
Including allocated overhead that doesn't change
practice_problems: You spent $500K on a feasibility study. Should this be included in NPV?
The project uses a warehouse you could rent for $100K/year. Is this relevant?
New product will steal 20% of sales from existing product. How to handle?

skos:definition: The principle of using only the additional cash flows caused by an investment decision in NPV analysis, excluding sunk costs and including opportunity costs.
